Re: Startup websites. Simplify and make it clear. Check out  the ‚ÄúStoryBrand‚Äù Template (Great book, ‚ÄúBuilding a StoryBrand‚Äù by Donald Miller.

I‚Äôve attached the template here, but your site needs to pass the ‚ÄúGrunt Test‚Äù - In 3 seconds, are there clear answers to these questions:
- What do you sell?
- How does it make my life better?
- How do I buy?

Another fun resource is <https://saaspages.xyz>.

_‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard that all good advice converges towards what can fit into a fortune cookie. So here‚Äôs my contribution: Always start by working your way back to your north star‚Äîwhat change do you want to bring to yourself and the world?_
_Then, try to take a few steps towards that north star that you think are valuable to the world, and do them really well. Then, try to make it sustainable so you can keep doing that.‚Äù_
_‚Äî_ Buster Benson

This last KERNEL module was very dense and stimulating and brought me back to some old topics of research/reflection.
Here I share some references/suggestions that came to my mind.

`On the *performativity of language*` as introduced in <https://kernel.community/module-5/incentives/#persuasion|module 5> (‚ÄúWhat constitutes persuasive language? Words which perform what they say.‚Äú) and `the *inertia of language*` that hides our unconscious internalisation of old paradigms (or, better, the ideologies that substantiate them), topic of <https://kernel.community/module-7/no-paradigm/|module 7> I would like to make a connection with the work of the famous French sociologist, *Pierre Bourdieu* (1930 ‚Äì 2002) which elaborated the very influential theory of _<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Bourdieu#Theory_of_habitus|habitus>_<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Bourdieu#Theory_of_habitus| and its >_<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Bourdieu#Theory_of_habitus|embodiment>_, <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Bourdieu#Symbolic_capital|symbolic capital> and finally <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_violence#Language|symbolic violence>.
In Bourdieu‚Äôs idea relations of domination in society are _reinforced through_ symbolic media, such as _language_, where even the ‚Äòoppressed‚Äô groups _unconsciously_ reiterate their status quo of their subordination with the use of the language of the dominants. This happens because of the _performative nature of speech acts_. I remember <@U016Q117G67> stressing very nicely this point of *the importance of using an appropriate language* in one of the KERNEL Fireside (now I can‚Äôt recall which one of them).

I cite (to amplify) <https://kernel.community/module-7/no-paradigm/|this passage> that I really liked from this final module:

_*Our history can be seen as the retroactive telling of various paradigmatic stories*;_
> _their inception, flourishing, and collapse; and how there always has been a new paradigm waiting to substitute for the collapsed one. These stories do not, however, sufficiently emphasize a recurrent and ubiquitous phenomenon [...] This phenomenon is best described as¬†*the inertia of language*._
_This inertia is both a symptom of paradigmatic stories, and *the dynamic force behind their telling*. It can be traced through facts like how the sun still ‚Äúrises‚Äù, even though we have known that it is the Earth‚Äôs horizon which dips into dawn, and rises into darkness._
> _Due to this inertia, language stores and offers for communicative usage many remnants of many obsolete paradigms._
_*If we accept these remnants in what we write, speak or hear, then we subject ourselves* to the unstoppable inertia behind it. This is something for which we must take individual responsibility:_
> _In human society language is so powerful that only violence can stop it. Where its power fails to serve my desires, it would be a mistake to blame such failure on the weakness of language. Rather *I should blame the weakness of my relation to language*. If I fail to notice that I think and speak, under the influence of language, *in patterns and constructs accumulated and preserved* in the junkyards of long since vanished paradigms, then this shows my lack of consciousness with regard to just *that power with which language can quickly make me spokesman for ideologies*, in which everybody is almost always ‚Äúright‚Äù at the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù time._
Connected to the ‚Äúpower of language‚Äù  here a nice *TED talk by* cognitive scientist *Lera Boroditsky* who conducts studies on _<https://www.ted.com/talks/lera_boroditsky_how_language_shapes_the_way_we_think?language=en|How language shapes the way we think>_ (and, I would say the other way around too, how we can see through the cultural differences across language semantics how words embody specific cultural beliefs and and way of representing the world).

Finally, still in relationship to performative speech and also *`horizontal conversations`*, I would like to propose a concept in philosophy of language and in particular of pragmatic theory, the <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_principle|cooperative principle> mainly represented by *Paul Grice*‚Äôs <https://www.sas.upenn.edu/~haroldfs/dravling/grice.html|four Maxims on Conversation>:
1. *The maxim of quantity* (_Don‚Äôt give more information or less than needed_)
2. *The maxim of quality (*_Try to make your contribution one that is true)_
3. *The maxim of relation (*_Be relevant)_
4. *The maxim of manner* (_Avoid ambiguity, obscurity of expression and unnecessary prolixity_)
I think those maxims are fundamental for the ethics in a conversation that wants to be peer-to-peer, transparent and positive-sum where ‚Äú<https://kernel.community/module-0/conversation/|Participants share trust, living within the same context>‚Äù.

Just about half way through this week‚Äôs modules and it has deeply moved me. All the little links that point to absolute gems on the internet. During one of the conversations with Apollo applicants, someone mentioned why he liked the trust module: ‚Äúit‚Äôs less focussed on building upon something you know and more focussed on questioning the foundations of your being, and getting to the reasons of developing what you‚Äôre developing‚Äù ‚Äî I feel that to be so true.

Came across this other little post today by Kent Beck (brilliant programmer) on his realisations and personal mission in life, for anyone interested: <https://www.facebook.com/notes/kent-beck/my-personal-mission/1811782322187957/>

‚Äú_There are ways my mission began the day I walked out of my first college CS course grumbling, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to change how people do this.‚Äù However, the whole picture only came into focus after decades of detailed work. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôd recommend to you if you‚Äôre beginning your career (you know, the first decade or two). Instead of coming up with high-falutin‚Äô words, write more programs._
_Once you have enough puzzle pieces, then you can arrange and rearrange them and see what picture pops up_.‚Äù

How about the whole ethereum community switch from twitter to some more decentralized social network?
reason: <https://www.evanvanness.com/post/624463633751195648/twitter-incompetence-in-one-small-image> and I believe you know many more similar stories.

<https://www.reuters.com/article/us-twitter-cyber-access-exclusive/exclusive-more-than-1000-people-at-twitter-had-ability-to-aid-hack-of-accounts-idUSKCN24O34E>
> More than a thousand Twitter employees and contractors as of earlier this year had access to internal tools that could change user account settings and hand control to others
Also: bZx was hacked -> no one is touching it anymore, twitter was hacked -> no one cares and everybody keeps twitting, what is wrong with us? :slightly_smiling_face:

Do you know any alternatives? I suggest <https://mastodon.online/about>

I'm a big on decentralization, but I'd like to point out that this particular problem likely won't go away if there would be a decentralized Twitter clone.
I write a little thread about this here: <https://twitter.com/William94029369/status/1283669135696830464>

In short, if the platform has a suspension mechanism, then it can most likely be gamed without the ability for a centralized authority to set things straight afterwards. If there is no suspension mechanism, it will most likely turn in to a toxic wasteland that makes Chernobyl look hospitable.

Something like peepeth on an L2 would be interesting. but I think the peepeth name leaves a lot to be desired.

Interesting points <@U016BTBS3MM>. Maybe decentralised blocks/unblocks would help here? In this example I‚Äôm sure enough of us could vouch for Evan and - as a community - agree to reinstate him (or rather, we never would have blocked him :D). Sounds like a job for kleros?

Perhaps. It would have to mitigate Sybil attacks, since otherwise someone sufficiently mitigated could mobilize their bot army to block/report. I don't know enough about Kleros to comment about their process, but my fear with any decentralized jury is that it likely has all the possible attacks of meatspace juries (collusion, bribery, marketing of law through spin PR, etc.) in addition to adding cyberspace vulnerabilities (bugs, hacks, etc.).

my point was that we don't trust anyone with private key to our wallet but we trust 1000 Twitter employees with our social reputation, and now after one of the biggest web2 hacks everybody is like nothing serious happened, we keep doing the same. isn't that hypocrisy?

from the other side, twitter alternative doesn't have to be decentralized and on a blockchain, it's enough it is encrypted and secure. but I see that in this case, the value that platform provides (number of followers) can outweigh any inconveniencies

I've heard people use the hypocrisy argument, and I don't totally agree. I suspect most of us have bank accounts and credit cards, in which we trust centralized authorities with our very monetary existence. I don't see this as a contradiction to 'not your keys, not your crypto'. We should bake decentralization into everything we're building whenever we can, totally agreed. I don't think it means we need to abandon everything else, especially without comparable alternatives.
The point I was really making, though, is that while I am all for making a decentralized Twitter, it will most likely not solve this problem, or will need to cope with a toxicity issue. I'd prefer the latter, frankly. We can make filters.

I think your second point is very close to the point I was making. Depending on which problem set you focus on, decentralization might not be the answer. I'm not far from being a censorship-resistance maximalist, so I'm for decentralizing all the things, but you have to understand what you're enabling if you do that.

So I have built a market making bot with a friend a year ago. It did very well on Coinbase when there were no fees. It uses simple rules to determine where to place bids / asks in the order book. Here is the marketing doc. Some of the things in there are not quite true, since we wrote it with the premise of what we will add in the future, and some parts, reading them now, seem to me a bit cheesy. Sharing it mainly to show the equity curves we have achieved. If anyone is interested in taking this further, or pivoting it, let me know. It is a bit sad that we have done so much work on it, but haven‚Äôt extracted any true value out of it.

I will be talking about it tomorrow on Wildcard‚Äôs tech share Friday

been thinking about <@U0173GGMBJQ> point regarding the context shift of free speech when attention was assumed to be abundant. If crypto solves the use case of "scarce digital asset" (signals) then money (defi) and agency/voting (daos) seem to be obvious use cases.

Attention seems to be a 3rd use case BUT traditional/online advertising seems to be technology dependent (broadcast tech - channeling my inner McLuhan). I guess tx volume is a signal? As gas prices increases and L2 becomes a thing, the tracking of signed messages will accrue value? Are there any projects measuring "interaction rate" (signed messages)?

Roll has talked about using personal tokens as measurements of engagement. Several people who have issued "social money" (their term) do token giveaways in their comms. The mechanism there is a scarcity play similar to the first X people who open my newsletter get my token free.

In the Kernel Slack, both <@U016HPVFV54> and <@U017E8XAW0G> have given away tokens as they test out the platform.

If attention is the scarce resource, then it's the audience who should be paid to consume it. Look at the timeshare model, you get a free hotel stay to listen to a hard sales pitch. This track talks about network harmful speech costing more, but take that a step back to the existing world. If someone is trying to sell me a harmful product/policy, I should be paid on a sliding scale (correlated to negative impact) to listen to it.

I like the direction that <http://microsponsors.io|microsponsors.io> is going - users price their attention. In the online advertising world there is ads.txt (<https://iabtechlab.com/ads-txt-about>), Balaji (in a recent chat with Vitalik and Juan Benet) was chatting about users having their own values.txt.
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DTxE9KV3YrE>

‚Ä¢ Use an ETH address as a log-in but protect the privacy of the user. So verify ownership and then selectively reveal/conceal information. Or maybe it‚Äôs like OAuth privs where ‚Äúthis app would like to view your USDC tx history.‚Äù

just read on the KERNEL lessons that the majority of world trade goes by sea; seems like common sense but never gave it too much thought until I read it

Hey Anar! Actually, it was not always that way - Historically, shipping by ocean took months [ships were slow and ports didn‚Äôt have efficient ways to unload the ships], was quite unpredictable [things fell off of the ship], and was not economical [you could only ship things by barrel].

In the 1960s, a guy came up with the idea to put full sized, standardized containers on ships. Standardization, scale led to mass adoption of ocean shipping today.

Anyways, here‚Äôs a great podcast about how ocean shipping achieved mass adoption if you are inclined: <https://www.tradetalkspodcast.com/podcast/133-how-one-man-and-some-metal-boxes-revolutionized-global-trade/>
